title: Mastery and Reflection – Prepositions with the Accusative (Motion Toward)
goals: Review all accusative prepositions and case endings
Demonstrate translation and comprehension of motion-toward meaning
Reflect on grammatical and moral order
Preview next week’s prepositions with the ablative

steps.speak: Salve! Today we review all our prepositions with the accusative — and celebrate your order in learning!
Let’s chant together: ad, in, per, super, ante. These all use the accusative when showing motion toward.
Repeat after me: ad puellam, in agrum, per viam, super aquam, ante domum.
Now translate aloud! ad puellam – to the girl, per viam – through the road, super aquam – over the water.
Mini quiz 1: Which case do these prepositions take?
Correct — the accusative! Mini quiz 2: What do the endings –am and –um show?
Right — motion toward. Mini quiz 3: What does Ordō mean?
Yes — right order! Both in grammar and in life.
Faith phrase: Ad Dominum currimus – We run to the Lord. Say it three times with joy.
Virtue reflection: God orders our words and our steps. Latin teaches us to notice direction and purpose.
Preview: Next week we’ll meet new prepositions that show rest or place — and use a different case!
Optime! You’ve mastered motion-toward order. Latin marches forward with you!
